abstract.p: Letter from Norman Siegel and David Leichtman, lawyers representing parents challenging cellphone ban, holds that actions by New York City Police Dept, Education Dept and principal of Middle School 54 regarding confiscation of cellphones raise serious policy and legal issues

block.p: Re ''Sweep at School Turns Up a Trove of Electronic Contraband'' (news article, June 1):
Re ''Sweep at School Turns Up a Trove of Electronic Contraband'' (news article, June 1):

The actions by the Department of Education, the New York City Police Department and the principal of Middle School 54 regarding the confiscation of cellphones raise serious policy and legal questions.

The cellphone ban is being challenged as being arbitrary and capricious, an abuse of authority and unconstitutional. Principals can and should allow the possession of, but not the use of, cellphones on school property. Making parents wait possibly as long as two weeks to retrieve their child's cellphone is overly punitive.
Parents should be able to retrieve the cellphones, when confiscated, at the end of the school day.
Finally, why is this policy applicable only in our public schools? New York City private schools do not have such a policy. Is there a double standard being applied?
Cellphones are a vital communication link between parents and their children on the way to and from school. We can regulate the use of cellphones. We should not ban them.
Norman Siegel David Leichtman New York, June 1, 2007
The writers are lawyers representing parents in challenging the cellphone ban.
